posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked: I am in college now, but Iâ€™m back home for spring break to help my team. They are having issues with the double solenoid they are using, and I have been working on it with them for a week and we canâ€™t figure out the problem. 75% of the time when we enable the robot, air just directly bleeds out of the solenoid exhaust holes. We have tried 3 solenoids, and one was brand new out of the bag so itâ€™s not the solenoid. The system is hooked up the same as we have hooked it up since I was in 9th grade, we have never had a problem with it. We have tried plugging the holes until the system builds up pressure, but it doesnâ€™t work because the second we unplug the holes it all just bleeds out through the solenoid exhaust.
Can you send a picture of your setup? Also if you are using u tubes in a manifold you need to switch to tube plugs instead.

posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked: I donâ€™t have a picture right now

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Without more info (i.e. a picture as @EHutson requested) about your setup, thereâ€™s not much anyone here can do beyond guess.

Rand:

The system is hooked up the same as we have hooked it up since I was in 9th grade, we have never had a problem with it.

By stating this, youre effectively claiming thereâ€™s no way it couldâ€™ve been assembled incorrectly, which can only serve to limit suggestions for assistance.  Mistakes do happen, and are often done in the most obviously (in retrospect) and yet easiest to overlook places.  Instead, just describe what you do have, ideally with as much detail as possible, and let the troubleshooting flow organically from there.

posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked: Alright thanks. I can send a picture tomorrow.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
To be honest, this sounds almost like someone swapped the exhausts and outputs.

Not that anybody would do that intentionally, but it can happen.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
And also, if you could provide the brand and model number of the solenoid valve you are using, that would be of help if things arenâ€™t something really obvious like things proposed above.

A properly plumbed solenoid valve (especially a double solenoid valve) should never bleed working air to the environment in a continuous fashion, which makes me like the idea of misplumbing as @EricH suggests.  If all your tubing is the same color, buying multiple (4) different tubing colors might help.  My old team used four separate colors (Iâ€™ll document the functions first, because the colors were based more on our team logo rather than logic):

high pressure (storage side lines, before the pressure regulator) [black]

working pressure unswitched

cylinder extend

cylinder retract

Having this color code helped us troubleshoot and avoid mistakes in pneumatics almost as much as the electrical wire color code.

posts.name: David_Raddatz
posts.cooked: Double check that your fittings in the ports are actually tight.

posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked:
This is the pneumatics system. Compressor splits off to pressure relief valve and the air tanks, air tanks flow into the working pressure, which goes to the double solenoid. The air donâ€™t always have issues with the solenoid bleeding, but it is so inconsistent. One day it wonâ€™t fill up at all even if we plug them until pressure builds up, the next day it just works. image 4032Ã—3024 2.53 MB image 3024Ã—4032 3.8 MB image 4032Ã—3024 3.66 MB image 3024Ã—4032 3.17 MB image 3024Ã—4032 3.06 MB

So to start I would try plugging that open valve. I would also make sure that your tubes are cut perfectly evenly. Also if none of those work I would change the solenoid. If tubes are not cut straight then that can cause air leakage.

posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked: We have tried 3 different solenoids, one was brand new out of the bag. We have tried plugging it until pressure builds up, but the exhaust valve never shuts.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: Those are 24V solenoids, is your PCM/PH set to 12V or 24V mode? If itâ€™s only getting 12V, that might not be enough to close the valve all the way and allow air to escape through the vent port

posts.cooked: Check the zip ties holding it to the robot.  There are small buttons on the solenoids for manual switching, Iâ€™m wondering if the zip ties might be holding one or both of those buttons - canâ€™t tell from the angle.

posts.name: Rand Faber
posts.cooked: I will have someone do that, thanks. I thought about it but couldnâ€™t get it out and didnâ€™t want to break it, Iâ€™ll have someone do that.

posts.name: Bill
posts.cooked:
EHutson:

So to start I would try plugging that open valve.

Donâ€™t plug the open port on the inlet side. That is the  exhaust port

posts.name: Mentor
posts.cooked:
I see one solenoid is 24V. Can you verify the other is also 24V? And the Pneumatics Control Hub is set to 24V?

Is it possible both solenoids are getting power at the same time? If so, that might cause the problem.

A double solenoid valve just needs a short pulse of electricity to shift the internal valve spool. A short pulse to the opposite solenoid shifts the spool to the opposite ports.

A single solenoid has a spring keeping the spool to one side. To shift the spool, you need to send a constant flow of electricity to the solenoid.

Heâ€™s a very good video explainer: https://youtu.be/tUq3NSZu0kA Note: the red flow is pilot pressure. Itâ€™s sort of like power steering in your car. With pilot pressure assisting, it takes very little power to shift the valve. However, if your regulator is set to very low pressure, the pilot pressure might not be enough to shift the valve completely, which could cause your problem.
